title: Ghana Misses Out On Talent Dev't – Report
text:
8 September 2015 13:51 CET Ghana Misses Out On Talent Dev't – Report By Daily Guide 
Haruna Iddrisu, Employment Minister Ghana must do more to develop and deploy talents in the country, the latest Global Competitive Report compiled by the World Economic Forum has stated. 
Even though the rankings show that Ghana overall climbed up from the 114 th position to 111 th out of 144 countries assessed in the report, it said education in the country was below the international level. 
It revealed that labour markets were characterized by inefficiencies. 
The report indicated that the country was not sufficiently harnessing new technologies for productivity enhancements- an example being ICT adoption rates which continue to be very low. 
Furthermore, it put the country's security situation at 111th, which was a concern. 
Ghana was able to reverse last year's downward trend this year largely as the result of slight improvements in its macroeconomic indicators, reversing last year's trend, although fiscal vulnerabilities persist. 
Government deficit stood at 10.8 percent of GDP in 2013, more than twice that of two years ago; government debt remains over 60 percent; and inflation is over 11 percent. 
With regard to strengths, public institutions were characterized by relatively high government efficiency (59th) and strong property rights (54th). In addition, the country's financial and goods markets were also relatively well developed (62nd and 67 th respectively). 
Additionally, the country was also ranked 11 th in Africa in terms of having a conductive environment for doing business with Mauritius emerging top of the category. 
While some economic critics believe the report should have focused on wooing foreign investors into the country to do business, others have argued that economic prospects of Ghana remained bright in view of the IMF and the World Bank's latest assessments. 
The report, which is the most comprehensive assessment of national competitiveness worldwide, looks at productivity and progress of countries and proffers solutions. 
By Samuel Boadi
